## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Solar Orbiter, STEREO A, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-02-29T19:29:06Z
## Message ID: 20240229-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-02-28T23:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~779 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 22 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -11/-42 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-02-28T23:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Solar Orbiter (glancing blow) and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach Solar Orbiter at 2024-03-02T04:00Z and STEREO A at 2024-03-03T18:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-03-04T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2024-02-28T23:12:00-CME-001):

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 21, 2024 - February 27, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-02-28T21:31:57Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-02-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-02-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240228-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 3 X-class flares, 11 M-class flares, 7 C-type CMEs, and 2 O-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-02-21T18:36Z may impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-02-24T16:44Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20240222-AL-003). The arrival of this CME may have been detected at L1 by ACE and DSCOVR at 2024-02-24T16:16Z (see notification 20240224-AL-001).

It was also estimated that the CMEs listed below would impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-02-21T18:36Z    STEREO A at 2024-02-24T14:26Z and Lucy at 2024-02-28T12:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20240222-AL-003).
2024-02-25T05:36Z    Lucy at 2024-03-03T06:00Z (minor impact), Mars at 2024-03-02T00:00Z (glancing blow), and OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-27T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240225-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.67 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp <= 4.67 occurred during the synoptic period 2024-02-27T03:00Z-06:00Z. This slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity may have been associated with the arrival of a weak transient event detected by ACE and DSCOVR at L1 on 2024-02-26.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A remained near or slightly above background levels for the entire reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to minor this reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-02-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-03-05T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently seven numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13590 (currently located at N18W48) produced ten M-class and three X-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity throughout the outlook period. Additionally, an unnumbered region visible near the eastern limb around latitude S20 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may exhibit activity as it rotates onto the Earth-facing disk.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity may be observed around 2024-03-02 due to the anticipated arrival of a C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-02-28T09:24Z (see notification 20240228-AL-001).

## Notes:

O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

** The incorrect STEREO A arrival month has been updated in this notification.  The expected arrival time should be 2024-03-02T18:00Z as indicated in the notification body now. **

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Interplanetary Shock
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-02-24T18:35:00Z
## Message ID: 20240224-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significant interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR at L1 at 2024-02-24T16:16Z. 

The shock is likely caused by CME with ID 2024-02-21T18:36:00-CME-001 (see notification 20240222-AL-003). Some magnetospheric compression and possible geomagnetic storm expected.

Activity ID: 2024-02-24T16:16:00-IPS-001.

## Notes: 

This interplanetary shock arrival may possibly have additional influence from the start of a coronal hole high speed stream due to a coronal hole centered at S20W20 at the time of the arrival, but whose most western edge was observed in UV imagery to have reached S15W45 at the time of the arrival. Analysis is ongoing.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare, 4 M-class flares, 1 R-type CME, 4 O-type CMEs, and 10 C-type CMEs (see details below).  

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-02-16T03:12Z may give a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-02-19T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-3 (below minor) (see notification 20240216-AL-004). The arrival of this CME may have been detected at L1 on 2024-02-20. Analysis of this arrival signature is ongoing.       

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-02-14T04:09Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-15T11:00Z, OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-15T16:00Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2024-02-17T01:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240214-AL-003).
2024-02-15T09:24Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-16T10:22Z, Juno at 2024-03-04T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240215-AL-001).
2024-02-16T01:36Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-17T06:25Z (see notification 20240216-AL-005).
2024-02-16T03:12Z    STEREO A at 2024-02-19T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240216-AL-004).
2024-02-16T07:23Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-18T16:17Z, Mars at 2024-02-21T11:00Z (glancing blow), Lucy at 2024-02-23T02:00Z (minor impact) (see notification 20240216-AL-003).
2024-02-17T13:16Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-19T07:00Z (glancing blow) (see notifications 20240217-AL-001 and 20240217-AL-002).
2024-02-19T23:24Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-22T02:29Z, Mars at 2024-02-24T06:00Z (glancing blow), Lucy at 2024-02-26T10:55Z (see notification 20240220-AL-001).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <= 3.33 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The solar energetic particle event detected by SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A during the previous reporting period (see notification 20240212-AL-007) persisted through the beginning of this reporting period. The flux of the >10 MeV protons at GOES and the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A subsided below their respective threshold of 10 pfu and 10^(-1) pfu/MeV on 2024-02-14. The flux of the 28.2-50.1 MeV and 15.8-39.8 MeV protons at SOHO subsided below the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV by 2024-02-15. On 2024-02-16, the particle environment observed at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A became slightly elevated but remained below threshold levels in response to the X2.5 flare from Active Region 13576 (S19W85) and associated C-type CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-02-16T07:23Z mentioned above (see notification 20240216-AL-003). Particle fluxes observed at all locations gradually subsided to near background levels through the remainder of the reporting period.

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle events detected at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-02-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-02-27T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently two numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13590 (N16E38) has recently produced many mid-level C-class flares and is likely to exhibit more flaring activity through the outlook period. An additional unnumbered active region observed towards the SE limb of the Earth-facing disk (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) has also been the source of recent C-class flaring and may continue to exhibit increased solar activity during the outlook period.
 
Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A coronal hole currently centered around S22E22 with a narrow extension towards the Earth-facing central meridian (as seen in available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective on or around 2024-02-24.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4.33 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp <= 4.33 occurred during the synoptic period of 2024-02-11T00:00Z-03:00Z. This slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2024-02-11T01:18Z which may have been associated with the shock arrival of the O-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-02-09T13:23Z (see notifications 20240209-AL-003, 20240209-AL-009, and 20240209-AL-011). Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2024-02-11T03:01Z (see notifications 20240211-AL-001 and 20240211-AL-004). This arrival was also detected by STEREO A at 2024-02-11T02:30Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

Two separate solar energetic particle events occurred during the reporting period, both of which were detected by STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES.

The first solar energetic particle event began on 2024-02-09 following the X3.3 flare peaking at 2024-02-09T13:14Z from Active Region 13575 (S37W110) (see notifications 20240209-AL-001 and 20240209-AL-002) and subsequent O-type CME first detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-02-09T13:23Z (see notifications 20240209-AL-003, 20240209-AL-009, and 20240209-AL-011). The flux of the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV at 2024-02-09T15:09Z (see notifications 20240209-AL-005 and 20240209-AL-006). At GOES, the integral flux of the >10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-02-09T15:30Z (see notifications 20240209-AL-007 and 20240209-AL-008). At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-02-09T15:52Z (see notification 20240209-AL-010). By the start of 2024-02-12, proton fluxes at GOES and STEREO A subsided to levels just below their respective threshold, while at SOHO the flux of the 15.8-39.8 MeV protons remained elevated, periodically hovering over the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV.

The second solar energetic particle event began on 2024-02-12 following the ER-type far-sided CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-02-12T06:36Z (see notification 20240212-AL-007). The flux of 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A and the flux of the 28.2-50.1 MeV protons at SOHO exceeded the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-02-12T07:41Z. At GOES the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded the threshold of 10 pfu starting at 2024-02-12T08:05Z and the flux of > 100 MeV protons briefly exceeded the threshold of 1 pfu at 2024-02-12T10:15Z (see notifications 20240212-AL-002, 20240212-AL-003, 20240212-AL-004, and 20240212-AL-006). The flux of > 100 MeV protons at GOES subsided below threshold levels after 2024-02-12T10:40Z while all other proton flux channels remained above their respective threshold levels at all three locations (GOES, SOHO, and STEREO A) through the remainder of the reporting period.


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle events detected at STEREO A, GOES, and SOHO.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-02-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-02-20T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently seven numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13575, which was responsible for multiple M-class flares and one X-class flare observed during the reporting period, rotated off the Earth-facing disk on 2024-02-08 and may continue to be the source of far-sided activity throughout the outlook period. Active Region 13576 (S17W63) and newly numbered Active Regions 13585 (N14E49) and 13586 (N25E70) have produced several M-class flares during the reporting period and are likely to exhibit additional flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. The SEP event observed during the reporting period on 2024-02-12 has and may continue to persist through the beginning of the outlook period. The integral flux of the >10 MeV protons at GOES and the 13-100 MeV proton flux at STEREO A recently subsided below their respective thresholds on 2024-02-14, but remain elevated above background levels. The flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels at SOHO are currently elevated near or just above the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - SEP (GOES, SOHO, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-02-12T13:52:27Z
## Message ID: 20240212-AL-006
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar energetic particle event detected by GOES, SOHO and STEREO A. 

At GOES the flux of > 100 MeV protons exceeded 1 pfu starting at 2024-02-12T10:15Z, and the flux of > 10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-02-12T08:05Z.

At Stereo A, the flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-02-12T07:41Z.

At SOHO, the flux of the 28.2-50.1 MeV protons channel exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting around 2024-02-12T07:41Z, while the flux of the 15.8-39.8 MeV protons channel had already been elevated, remaining close and periodically above the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV following the previous SEP event (2024-02-09T15:09:00-SEP-001).

NASA Spacecraft at MEO, GEO and other high-altitude orbits and high-inclination LEO, as well as at STEREO A can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2024-02-12T10:15:00-SEP-001.

## Notes: 
Prior to this SEP event (2024-02-12T10:15:00-SEP-001) the particle fluxes at all three locations (GOES, SOHO and STEREO A) had already been significantly elevated following the SEP event with Activity ID 2024-02-09T15:09:00-SEP-001 (see notifications 20240209-AL-005, 20240209-AL-006, 20240209-AL-007, 20240209-AL-008, 20240209-AL-010). At GOES and STEREO A, proton fluxes had already subsided to below threshold levels prior to current event, while at SOHO the flux of the 15.8-39.8 MeV protons channel still periodically exceeded the threshold of 10^(-1) pfu/MeV prior to the current SEP event.

The source of the SEP event is likely a significant CME from behind the SW limb that was detected by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-02-12T06:36Z. This CME is currently being analyzed.

## Summary:

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2024-02-10T07:00Z.

Estimated speed: ~967 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 39 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 6/-37 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2024-02-10T07:00:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Psyche, Solar Orbiter, and STEREO A.  The leading edge of the CME will reach Psyche at 2024-02-15T08:15Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-02-12T18:43Z, and STEREO A at 2024-02-12T20:46Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-02-12T22:31Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-6 (below minor to moderate).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 13 M-class flares, 13 C-type CMEs, and 3 O-type CMEs (see details below). 
   
Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-02-01T08:00Z may impact NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-02-04T02:16Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 4-6 (below minor to moderate) (see notification 20240201-AL-001). The arrival of this CME may have been embedded in the coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2024-02-04 (see notification 20240205-AL-002). STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments may also have detected the arrival of this CME around 2024-02-04T10:30Z.

Additionally, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-02-02T04:17Z and associated with an M1.1 flare from Active Region 13571 (S18E60) peaking at 2024-02-02T03:01Z may give a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-02-05T10:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-3 (below minor) (see notification 20240202-AL-002). 

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

2024-02-01T08:00Z  Psyche at 2024-02-05T18:11Z, Solar Orbiter at 2024-02-03T18:39Z, STEREO A at 2024-02-04T03:59Z (see notification 20240201-AL-001)
2024-02-01T21:36Z  Lucy at 2024-02-09T00:00Z (minor impact), OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-04T00:07Z (see notification 20240202-AL-001)

2024-02-02T13:36Z  Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-04T00:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240202-AL-003).
2024-02-05T07:48Z  Solar Orbiter at 2024-02-08T16:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240205-AL-001)
2024-02-06T02:53Z  Lucy at 2024-02-13T00:00Z (glancing blow), OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-08T06:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240206-AL-002)
2024-02-06T12:00Z  Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-07T18:59Z (see notification 20240206-AL-003)

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton fluxes at GOES, SOHO and STEREO A remained below threshold levels for the entire reporting period. At the beginning of the reporting period, the particle environment was somewhat elevated after a solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES in the previous reporting period (see report 20240124-7D-001). The particle environment had returned to near background levels by 2024-02-06 when a brief minor particle flux elevation occurred following an M2.2 and an M4.2-class flares from Active Region 13575 (S34W65) and the associated C-type CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-02-06T02:53Z mentioned above (see notification 20240206-AL-002).

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-02-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-02-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate to possibly high levels during the outlook period. There are currently ten Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13575 which was responsible for four most recent M-class flares, including an M5 class flare at the start of the outlook period, is rotating off of the Earth-facing disk today but could still produce some activity in the next two days. Active Region 13576 (S16E36) was responsible for the majority of M-class flaring observed during the reporting period and may continue to exhibit flaring activity as it transits the Earth-facing disk during the outlook period. One more unnumbered Active Region may soon be rotating onto the eastern limb around latitude N15 as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO.
 
Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low to minor levels during the outlook period. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity might be observed around 2024-02-10 due to a possible glancing blow from a S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2024-02-06T13:48Z.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 24, 2024 - January 30, 2024
##
## Message Issue Date: 2024-01-31T21:52:24Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-24T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2024-01-30T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20240131-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 6 M-class flares, 10 C-type CMEs, and 3 O-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-01-29T04:38Z may give a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth at about 2024-01-31T08:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 3-4 (below minor) (see notifications 20240129-AL-009 and 20240129-AL-010).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs are predicted to impact the following locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2024-01-27T03:36Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-01-29T18:19Z (see notification 20240127-AL-001).
2024-01-27T04:24Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-01-29T18:19Z (see notification 20240127-AL-001).
2024-01-28T02:48Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-01-30T16:00Z (glancing blow).
2024-01-29T02:00Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-30T09:52Z (see notification 20240129-AL-010).
2024-01-29T04:38Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-01-30T09:52Z, STEREO A at 2024-01-31T04:02Z, Mars at 2024-02-02T02:00Z (glancing blow), and Lucy at 2024-02-02T23:43Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-009 and 20240129-AL-010).
2024-01-30T00:24Z    OSIRIS-APEX at 2024-02-01T14:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20240130-AL-002).
2024-01-30T21:12Z    Parker Solar Probe at 2024-02-01T05:42Z (see notification 20240131-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3.67 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

There was a solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES. At STEREO A, the flux of the 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-01-29T05:11Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-002 and 20240129-AL-004). At SOHO, the flux of one or more of the >15.8 MeV protons channels exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2024-01-29T06:08Z (see notification 20240129-AL-007). At GOES, the integral flux of the >10 MeV protons exceeded 10 pfu starting at 2024-01-29T06:15Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-006 and 20240129-AL-008). This solar energetic particle event is associated with the M6.8 flare peaking at 2024-01-29T04:38Z from Active Region 13559 (N25W70) (see notifications 20240129-AL-001 and 20240129-AL-003) and subsequent O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery at 2024-01-29T04:38Z (see notifications 20240129-AL-009 and 20240129-AL-010). The enhanced particle environment at STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES began to notably subside on 2024-01-30, decreasing below each spacecrafts respective threshold and remaining slightly elevated above background levels through the end of the reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate to high this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected at STEREO A, SOHO, and GOES.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2024-01-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2024-02-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. There are currently five Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13559 and 13561, which were responsible for multiple M-class flares observed during the reporting period, have rotated off the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13567 (N20E58) has produced several C-class flares since rotating onto the Earth-facing disk around 2024-01-30 and may continue to exhibit flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity could be observed on or around 2024-02-01 due to a possible glancing blow from the O-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2024-01-29T04:38Z (previously described above). Additionally, coronal hole structures currently centered near S18W20 and S35E15 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO AIA) may become geoeffective during the outlook period on or around 2024-02-02 and 2024-02-04, respectively.
